Fields.DialogueText: You find a place for the bell yet, Captain?
Of all people, Exeter, I would have thought you'd have an idea for that.
And tell you what to do with your present?

Fields.MenuText: How to use a two-ton church bell isn't exactly common kowledge.

Fields.DialogueText: It doesn't have to be useful to be beautiful.
I appreciate the effort you go to for your gifts.
Thank you!
Unconventional though they may be.
The best kind.
However, I'm surrendering control of this to you while we're at sea, citing INPF code.
... There's a rule for that?
I was surprised too. Unofficially, it's the "let the Belle clean up her messes" clause.
Not that I consider your gift a-

Fields.MenuText: It's not just an ornament?
Would you?

Fields.DialogueText: It's the thought that counts, Captain.
That's your decision, isn't it?
No, Captain, I understand. Let me find somewhere for-
*ALARM*
Leave it. It's not hurting anything where it is.
Depending on the trajectory of the Morgana shells, it might help.
@BATTLE
Pass me those crisps?
Of course, Captain!
Quite the spread you've got here.
I thought it fitting to bring a bit of home aboard. In an edible sense, this time. Easier to digest.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose you think you're very clever.
You don't have to apologize for the bell, you know.
Especially with a little cider.

Fields.DialogueText: I come by it honestly, Captain.
Oh, I'm not. But it never hurts to be considerate.
Scrumpy! Auntie Warspite swears by it. She and I were both laid down in Devonport, you know.
You're not helping the crew with the food?
Haven't been hungry, Captain. Belles don't need it.
Looks like I'm lucky. I've heard the most bizarre rumors about some of the others' habits.
Habit's what it's really all about. Really good food should be a celebration. Unless I've done or heard about something to really stir my blood, I don't like to indulge.
Courtesy of the host. I don't eat until everyone else is served.
Come to think of it, I don't think I've seen you eat for the past few days.
*ALARM*
Here's your chance.
Yes! I have to admit, Captain, that hog's pudding was getting tempting.
@BATTLE
There's the Morganas, Exeter. Are you ready?
They shall sample my blade!
@BATTLE
Another victory for the songs!

Fields.MenuText: For now.
If only we could make it stick.
Do you write music as well?

Fields.DialogueText: They'll be back, Captain, but we'll be better.
We serve as an example to our people. That's enough for me.
Not like Cousin Belfast or Miss New Orleans, but I'll sing anything you put in front of me!
Still... yes, it would be nice to send at least one to the bottom of the sea.
If we'd just pursue them a little further...
No, Captain. The Morganas know when they're beaten, but they also know a safe retreat when they need to make one.
You're saying that they'd be luring us into a trap.
We can only assume, Captain.
I've also noticed you were the first to stop firing.
... As I said, Captain, the Morganas know when they're beaten. War is ugly, but there is room yet for mercy toward a retreating foe.
Suppose they feign a retreat.
My sword is sheathed, but it remains at my side. Honour is not a handicap.
See that it's not.
Captain, transmission from...
From?
Morganas. I know that haunted look, officer. You've done your duty. Let us handle it.
Ma'am.
Morgana. State your business.

Fields.MenuText: What's she saying?
This is pointless.
It's a trap.

Fields.DialogueText: Quiet.
The enemy have asked to speak. We will at least hear them out.
One I trust we'll be equal to.
... Hmm.
Well?
Coordinates. An appointed time and place.
Pitched battle? That's not their style.
Parley.
With the Morganas? Not a lot of precedent for that that ended well.
Not these Morganas. The one I spoke to won't be joining us today...
@BATTLE
I don't like this, Exeter.
Well, you don't have to suffer through eating it.
No, your groats pudding is delicious. I'm talking about the Morgana nonsense.
This is different, Captain. When the Morganas speak, they're usually all chaos and despair.
This is different how?
A concrete time and place, Captain. When we get something coherent out of these witches, they're trying to tell us something.

Fields.MenuText: It can't be anything good.

Fields.DialogueText: It probably isn't.
This could jeopardize the whole mission.
Or this could be a turning point in it. Please, Captain. Let me at least hear this one out before I send her back to Hell.
... Fine. I admit I'm just as curious as you are about Morgana "diplomacy." But it's on your head if it goes south.
I accept full responsibility if it does.

Fields.MenuText: Or they're just taking advantage of our better nature.
Why not just fight us?

Fields.DialogueText: Chivalry is nothing to be ashamed of.
They could. They evolve every time they do. That's why if they just want to talk... I'm willing to listen.
Damn. Speaking of Morganas... your pudding's going to get cold.
I think I can live with it.
@BATTLE
There she is. You're sure you know what you're doing?
She's coming around. If she wanted to attack us she's had plenty of chances.
There's a greeting shot. Acknowledge.
Acknowledged.
Now let me work.

Fields.MenuText: Be careful.
If she tries anything funny we start shooting.
You're out of your mind.

Fields.DialogueText: Prudence, always.
You won't even need to give the order.
Thank goodness, or we'd never have gotten this far.
Morgana. We have come as you requested. What is your proposal?
Ugly out here today.
Patience, Captain. The Morgana patrol is exactly as my contact described.
Your contact the Morgana.
She'll come to us once the battle is won.
That's exactly what worries me.
@BATTLE
... I see. Brace yourself.
Exeter, what-
*BOOM*
Right in her magazine. I guess that concludes negotiations.
It... it was supposed to.
Exeter?
We'll settle in with a cuppa, Captain. It's a long story.
There was no time, Captain. The Morgana threatened the River Exe itself if I responded any other way.
And what do we have to show for it? Some vague promise that they won't touch the area?
It's held up so far, hasn't it? When was the last time any were sighted on my side of the Channel?
@BATTLE
Grr... I should have seen it coming.
You should have consulted me before you fired that shot.
Exmouth, Captain. Dawlish Warren. Starcross. Exton. How many of those are you willing to sacrifice? Exeter herself is four miles inland. That's well within my range, and it's well within theirs!

Fields.MenuText: So I'm just along for the ride, am I?
What have you gotten us into?
So what does she want now?

Fields.DialogueText: If it keeps the Morganas from scourging the Exe, then yes, I suppose you are!
I'm so sorry, Captain. Please understand that I'm trying to save as many lives as possible.
Not what, Captain. Who.
She... she offered me her neck for a fatal blow. You can't deny the opportunity that represents.
But it didn't work.
I still can't believe this. Why didn't you consult me?
Exactly. Now she is free to exact her price... and strike one on me.
Exeter...
Captain, I know! I made a mistake! But I thought if it was a difference between risking hundreds of us and thousands of civilians we're sworn to defend...
Exeter-
But she doesn't care for the lives of her crew. It was never an equal bargain to begin with, and I was so certain I could destroy one of these things for good, and-
Exeter! Get yourself together.
But if I'd only made it count-
There was no making it count. We know this now. Besides, can't you just... not let her attack you?
It's... complicated, Captain.
Try me.
... All right. Where to begin...
*ALARM*
We don't have time for this. We're making time after.
Sure I can. We've delivered a lot of fatal shots under much less-
I'm sorry. I didn't explain properly. The deal was, if I sank her in that one shot, she'd stay sunk. We would never see her, or another iteration of her, or however it works, again.
So Exeter's in the clear.
The city and its environs, yes. As long as we draw breath... and after, if it comes to that. Our Morgana adversary promised, and she seems to be holding to it.
But only if you hold up your end of the bargain.
One shot now for one shot later.
So the part where you're bound to fight the Morgana on her terms-
-Is not just between her and me, Captain. I bought the lives of thousands with a single shot.
Not to mention the lives of your captain and crew.
I gave my word.

Fields.MenuText: Actions speak louder.
And you trust the Morgana's?
So armor up.

Fields.DialogueText: Few louder than a merciless terror attack on the city that gave me my name.
I trust the continued safety of Exeter and her river. You can't deny it's been quiet.
There's only so much I can do. Who knows when she'll come back, and with what weapons?
Honor only works on enemies that have any.
Belles and Morganas play by different rules... but it's worth testing the proposition that there are rules nonetheless.
I'll level with you, Exeter. What you did was reckless. Maybe even naive.
Yes, Captain. Thank you.
We're in this together, and we'll find a way out of this. There's nowhere safer than aboard you, Exeter.
Long may that be the case.
But it was also a reasonable shot at killing one of these things. And if it takes the heat off the coast, so much the better. Your heart was in the right place.
But as long as we're making deals, let me propose one. Instead of calling this whole thing off immediately, I'm going to help you figure out how to survive it.
We can try to evacuate the ship when she comes. With enough warning, we might be able to reduce us down to a skeleton crew that-
Exeter.
And I'll tell you right now, I'm not above cheating.
At the same time, though, you will not let a Morgana so much as sneeze at my crew - yourself included - without notifying me first. Am I understood?
I-
The foredeck's clear. You're sure you want to do this?
Consider it therapy. Besides, we don't want a stray bullet harming anyone.
Got your sidearm?
Got your shield?
Right here, Captain!
Fire one!
Again!
Fire two!
Once more!
Fire three!
Flawless. Thank you, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: How much does that thing weigh?
How will this help against the Morgana?
Out of curiosity, if you hadn't blocked...

Fields.DialogueText: Less than the bell, but more than you can handle.
It won't. But it makes me feel better.
It would have hurt quite a bit. But nothing like a shell to the boiler.
There's definitely value in training. Keeps one sharp.
And sane.
Don't worry, Exeter. You're going to beat this.
It's not the what, Captain. Well, it is the what, but the when is a factor too. Do you know the story of Sir Gawain and the Green Knight?
In passing. Gawain had a year and a day to prepare, didn't he?
While this Morgana could show up again at any time. The not knowing... it's maddening sometimes.
I can only imagine. Shall we try with your sword this time?
I'm sensing Morganas, Captain. Put a pin in that, though. It's intriguing!
@BATTLE
Tarot cards, Captain?
I thought we'd narrow down that "when" you were losing so much sleep over.
I feel like I'm trapped in a room with New Orleans.
One of the crew offered to lend them. They're noticing your silence at the meetings, you know.
... Rwy'n gwybod. They wouldn't understand.
So let's try and understand a little better.
Captain, this is ridiculous.

Fields.MenuText: You don't think there might be something to this?
I thought you wanted to know when you were to...
We won't know until we try.

Fields.DialogueText: Belles exist. I'm standing right in front of you. This is just... no.
I'm not.
Thank you, but no.
I'll tell you how it works. It'll acknowledge some sort of impending struggle and spit out exactly how I'd respond anyway. Charity, training, and steadfastness before adversity.
How does it work, then?
Besides, we're not getting a specific time and place out of this. That's not how tarot works.
I'll give these back, then.
Give them to me. I'll return them at the next session.
*ALARM*
... And I'll make sure there is a next one.
@BATTLE
I'm beginning to think this is a hobby of yours.
Moving boxes? It keeps me trim, you know!
What's the gift this time?
Something fairly simple this time, Captain. No church bells for the crew.
Could you even carry six hundred of those?
I wouldn't enjoy it. Besides, I picked them up something more useful. Open one of those crates if you like.
Compasses. That is useful.
Look on the back, Captain.
Your coat of arms.
Something to remember me by wherever they go.
After the war's over.
Ideally, yes. But one never knows.

Fields.MenuText: You're not going to die. It's impossible.
You're unforgettable already.
You don't actually believe that.

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing's impossible, Captain.
Oh, goodness, you are incorrigible.
What I believe doesn't enter into it.
I'm still not sure I believe in whatever passes for Morgana honor.
You don't have to. But they're not going to pass up an opportunity to sink a Belle for good.
Well, then... when are we distributing these?
Dinner, perhaps. We've got some Morganas to strike down before that.
@BATTLE
You certainly didn't pass up your opportunity to sink her.
And I failed. But say they make the offer again. Who's to say a stronger Belle might not succeed? It might even be me.
I guess even they recognize an opportunity when they see one.
I gave those cards back to Ensign Laveau.
Did you tell him why we had them?
Did you?
It's your story to tell. I just mentioned you might be looking for some clarity during the war.
True enough, I suppose. I did talk to York about it.
For a given value of "talk."
Well, yes. It's been a while since I heard her really speak.

Fields.MenuText: What did she say?

Fields.DialogueText: Essentially, to stop being stupid.
She's such the elder sister. Always got an opinion about how I prosecute the war...
An opinion you seek out.
I love her, but she can be so cold sometimes. Her first question was-
-Why you're holding up your end of the bargain.
You two would get along famously.
I still don't quite understand it myself.
They may look different and scary, but Morganas are reflections of their origins just the way we Belles are.
That's a disturbing thought.
Ruin... Destruction... Fire... Let them be weapons of war. They don't know hope or compassion or chivalry. That's where I come in. And part of chivalry is honesty.
Even if it might get you killed.
It won't, Captain. I think talking to my sister has made me more sure of that.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we should have asked the cards when she'll awake.
But she understands you.

Fields.DialogueText: Why stop there? Perhaps this war can be won with astrology. I didn't tell her about the cards, incidentally.
She understands my heart, and how it aches and soars. I'm waiting on the soaring right now.
*ALARM*
Besides, if that one Morgana has my number, there's no way we can lose today!
@BATTLE
Looks like they're reconsidering, Captain. They're breaking off!
I don't like this. Maintain distance.
It's a full retreat. The rules of engagement-
*ALARM*
Damn it! They're right on top of us!
@BATTLE
Finally it's over.

Fields.MenuText: We shouldn't have fallen for it.
Next time, no quarter.
How could they have pulled something so low?

Fields.DialogueText: We were ready. That's what matters.
I hate that I'm tempted to agree.
I wish I'd asked myself that before.
I think word's spreading about your refusal to fire on retreating foes.
We're better than that, Captain.
The Morganas aren't. They're not accountable to human laws.
Moral or otherwise.
So what do you propose to do? Wait until they fool us again?
There's a reason I train for these things, Captain. Doing bad for good reasons is the first step to doing it for bad reasons.
Sometimes I think you're too chivalrous for your own good.
Gan Grist, you sound like my sister.
You're certain you can do this?
Certainly I'm certain.
It's just that your sword's a lot thinner than-
Digon o siarad. Fire!
If you say so...
I hope I've assuaged your fear, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: At this rate you won't have to wait for the Morgana.
You're fast. Impossibly fast.
I'm one thing. Morganas are another.

Fields.DialogueText: It'll take more than a squire with a sidearm to stop me!
Keep flattering me and I'll be tempted to start catching these bullets!
True. Perhaps we should upgrade to my guns.
You know, a little ruthlessness wouldn't be out of place now and again.
War's war, Captain. We have our objectives and they have theirs. They've just decided to be savage and murderous in attaining them. We are neither.
That doesn't strike you as fighting with one hand tied behind your back?
It's more difficult to fight one-handed, I'll admit. That doesn't make it a weakness.
If the Morganas perceive it as such, that is their downfall.
Looks like we're coming up on a few. Up for a little proof of concept?
When they're up to their dirty tricks again. These foes just look conventionally nasty.
@BATTLE
(With a flick of her blade, Exeter deflects the Captain's bullet.)
Thought experiment, Exeter?
Oh, I suppose so.
If you're playing cards with an opponent and you know they're cheating-
I beat you fair and square at that baccarat game in port.
Not the point.

Fields.MenuText: You can't expect to win if your opponent isn't playing by the rules.
Would you cheat to beat them?
I thought gambling was beneath you anyway.

Fields.DialogueText: It just means I have to play the better game.
I don't need to.
I'm a knight, not a priest.
I'm not trying to get you to change your ways. I just want to understand.
Cheaters cheat because it's easy. It's the swiftest, most painless path to victory. And that's exactly why they always lose in the long run.
You saw that bloody feigned retreat. They know how to cheat. They don't know how to win.
Turning our respect for fair play against us upsets the balance... but winning anyway upsets it back. I think I see now.
And now you're doubly aware there's no way you can beat me.
Hey, just what is that supposed to-
Here they come, Captain! Keep the focus on my victory!
@BATTLE
Do you think it'll be safe again soon?
The seas?
And the world. There's so much of it out there I can't wait to see.
Where do you want to go most?
Honestly, Captain... Rome.
Bit fascist right now, isn't it?
The city will be there when Mussolini is gone. Besides, if King Arthur can take the war to the Roman walls, so can I!

Fields.MenuText: You're aware that he wasn't real.
What does he have to do with anything?
What did a British king have against Rome?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe not, but he means more than the man he was. Or might have been.
What else are legends for than to teach a lesson?
Henry VIII found an excuse.
To see an empire rise and fall... to watch an entire religion grow from a cult of the downtrodden to a worldwide creed... It's almost as glorious as Exeter!
Nothing can top your home, can it?
The world is full of beautiful places, but I only have room in my heart for a single home.
That makes it all the more important to defend.
I could go on and on... but I'm sensing Morganas not far off.
Never mind travel. We need to make the world safe for casual conversation.
@BATTLE
Captain, a quick request...
Anything, Exeter. What do you need?
You've got the crew for that.
Yes, well, it's not the same. Do you call one of them in here to tidy up when you need to think?
I suppose not. All right, Exeter, I'll steer clear.
Thanks, Captain. That means a lot.
Anything for a friend.
... Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Still need something?
Don't you have some cleaning to do?
That's me.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps it's silly, but...
It can wait. If you've got a moment...
Yes. I was wondering, you see...
Have you ever caught someone in a lie? Someone you trusted?
Rarely, but it has happened.
How did you deal with it?
Well... if they were close to me, there was generally a reason for it. It might not have been a good reason, but... how to put this?
They did what they did not because they had anything to gain from the lie, but because they thought I couldn't handle the truth.
Keep away from the magazines. I'm doing some cleaning over there.
So what happened next?
That depended entirely on how they acknowledged their role in the situation.
*ALARM*
Just when things were getting good.
I'll meet you on the bridge.
... Exeter. Are you sure there isn't anything you want to tell me?
Nothing, Captain. I'll bring it up at the meeting.
@BATTLE
I did as you suggested, Captain. I brought up the wager.
In your therapy group?
I was... surprised. None of them reacted the way I thought they would.

Fields.MenuText: How did they react?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, there was silence. And lots of hugging after.
I think they've read the story too.
Or they know you wouldn't endanger their lives for personal gain.
Well, they know what they signed up for, serving with a Belle. But they really just asked questions.
Like "what were you thinking?"
More along the lines of "how are you going to get one over on her?"
If you're going to do something the hard way, get really good at it.
They seem to think so. Some of them were quite keen on watching... whenever she comes around again.

Fields.MenuText: Sounds like you dodged a bullet.

Fields.DialogueText: Several.

Fields.MenuText: They really do trust you.

Fields.DialogueText: I was surprised too.
And that question... should have been easier to answer. But they appreciate my training regimen.
Any sign of when that might be?
Nothing concrete, Captain. But I've been feeling a chill lately... like I'm being watched; sized up.
*ALARM*
It's not her.
How do you know?
She would have sent a message.
I thought they didn't do chivalry.
They surprise me more and more every day.
@BATTLE
Captain, you're going to want to have the lady listen to this.
Morganas?
One of the other radiomen is restrained below. It's Morganas.
Say no more, sailor. Let's have a listen.
What does she say?
... How nice of her. It's on our patrol route. We won't have to go our of our way.
When?
Soon.

Fields.MenuText: What do you mean, "soon?"
That's got to be a coincidence.
That's not helpful.

Fields.DialogueText: Hopefully the same thing York meant.
If it is, Captain, the Morganas have a knack for them. Or espionage.
It's the best we're going to get from her.
Are you ready?
More than ready. Now I know today's Morganas won't be a threat to us.
You're that confident?
Even they have professional courtesy. That, or they respect each other's prey.
@BATTLE
There she is.
You've got this, Exeter.
Captain... you know you're free to get to safety.
I can't be responsible for your death!
I could have ordered you not to do this, you know. Any of it.
You- that-
Couldn't I have?
She's going to score a hit on me, right in the powder magazine-

Fields.MenuText: I know.
And then you're going to burn her to the waterline.
And now that you've told the crew, they'll take precautions.

Fields.DialogueText: You're much calmer about this than I thought you'd be.
The thought had crossed my mind.
If even one of them died because of me...
She'll hit you, per your arrangement. Right where you hit her. Right where your armour's thickest.
... You remembered?
I'm your captain. How could I forget?
Now get out there. You have a wager to win.
Why would I want to do that?
@BATTLE
Well, damn. I guess I expected this to happen, but... damn.
Expected what to happen?
Gah! Captain, don't scare me like that!

Fields.MenuText: What possible threat could I pose to you?
Hiding something, are we?
Sorry. I'll announce myself next time.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, none, but give a girl some warning!
No, in fact, we are not!
No, it's quite all right. I should have sensed you coming.
Goodness. This corridor's a ruin.
Still patching up from the free hit, I'm afraid.
Must have lost some cargo too. Wood everywhere and... wait. What's this?
That... was once a church bell.
The one you got from the cathedral?
Which other one could there have been?
This was your spring cleaning project? I suppose this was a more sensible place for it, but...
Sensible, nothing. It was vital. A little extra armor never goes amiss.
But how did you-
I didn't know. I just thought like a Morgana and asked myself where my strongest point was weakest. Bloody good thing I did, or I'd be the world's most chivalrous reef.
Have you decided how you'll get this out of here?
The Morganas are out in force today, Captain. Let's blast us some breathing room and then we can think.
@BATTLE
Captain, incoming transmission. It's Morgana in nature.
Let me handle this one.
What's she saying?
Well?
She congratulates us on our victory. She... she couldn't have endangered the humans better herself.
... Give me that microphone.
Captain--
Right now. Ahem...
You don't want to hear it, Captain. Our radiomen can't listen without--

Fields.MenuText: Good thing I'm the captain.
You chose me for a reason. Let me use it.
Quiet.

Fields.DialogueText: It's dangerous for humans, no matter who they are.
She's pure evil. Don't listen to her!
Yes, Captain.
Whatever you're saying to my Belle, it stops now. She beat you once. She can do it again.
... We care not for the size of the grave. Only that you help us dig one.
What the hell?
Exeter, what does she mean?
Let me work, Captain. Then we'll talk.
@BATTLE
That's right.
No grand plan to sink a Belle for good.
None.
They just wanted to see you play their game.
They know now that I'm willing to spend human lives. Everything else is just negotiating price.
Exeter...
How does that make me different from them?

Fields.MenuText: Don't let them get to you.
You wanted to save lives. They wanted to end them.
You're on our side.

Fields.DialogueText: I told you I had to think like a Morgana to beat her. I didn't realize how right I was.
At what cost!?
I said I'd never do anything that wasn't in your best interest. I guess that means I'll do anything.
It was a test of Gawain's character. A plot to sow discord among the Round Table and frighten the queen to death.
Which didn't happen here.
We can drive off the Morganas all day with superior weaponry and tactics. The only thing they can break is our spirit. As long as we have that, there's no way we can lose.
They failed. You succeeded. That's all that matters.
So. The River Exe, Exeter, its surroundings... the Morganas never cared about it.
Do you remember how the story of Gawain and the Green Knight ended? Why it happened?
It's encouraging, Captain. I just wish... I wish I could have been honest with you from the start.
*ALARM*
Save your apology. We've got more Morganas to defeat.
@BATTLE
It was a test of Gawain's character, too. What does it say about me that I'm willing to sacrifice my friends?
The same thing it says about me. It says you're fighting a war. You care about how you fight it. You wouldn't ask anything of the crew you wouldn't ask of yourself. That fact should be enough.
Captain, what are the crew wearing?
Oh, you noticed the medals?
They're not like any I've ever seen. In fact, they're all shaped... really quite irregularly.
Couldn't melt it down at sea, but these will do until we find someone who can.
Are they... fragments of the bell?
Gathered from the wreckage in the magazine.
When did you have the time for this?
You got so caught up cooking after that last engagement. I didn't want to disturb you.
I'm flattered, Captain... but why?

Fields.MenuText: To remind us of who's protecting us.
Why not?
Because we can always trust on being saved by the Belle.

Fields.DialogueText: But I roped us into it in the first place, Captain. Unilaterally.
Because I lied, Captain, with the crew's lives at stake!
If you're going to make puns, they're tolerable wrapped in a compliment. Even for a liar like me.
There's more to the story, you know. Remember how Gawain survived?
The enchanted girdle. Sir Bertilak's wife gave it to him after he refused her advances.
You held your neck out for the Morgana to strike, knowing it would save lives. You baited her into attacking where you were strongest.
I suppose you're right, Captain. Then the bell fragments are like Gawain's green sash?
Everything you did, you did with your life on the line, in the service of a higher cause. And you admitted when you weren't perfect in doing it. That sounds pretty chivalrous to me.
A reminder to us all to be as honest as you.
Takes one to know one, doesn't it?
These Morganas don't stand a chance.
@BATTLE
Yes, you lied... to the crew and to the Morgana. Your lies saved us all, and we're stronger for them.
You're sure you want to do this?
I never joke about my training, Captain!
All right, here we go. Dismiss arms.
Dismissed.
Fire one!
Again!
Fire two!
Tân uffern. Again!
Fire three!
Ooh! That's hot. Good thing I'm wearing gloves.
You caught it?
And dodged the first two. Here, you can have it back.

Fields.MenuText: You keep it, to remember how far you've come.
I might just keep it. Maybe build a little shrine.
Is it magical now that you've touched it?

Fields.DialogueText: I do owe Exeter Cathedral a gift... Do you think they'd make a relic of it?
The finest paperweight on the seas!
Oh, Captain, I'm not the Lady of the Lake! ... That I know of.
Supernatural reflexes... Any other deals I should know about?
Definitely not, Captain. And you'll be one of the first to know if there is.
So you just catch bullets for your health.
And I catch shells for yours.
I feel healthier already.
What luck! It looks like we've got company. Keep this up, Captain, and we might just live forever.
Exeter! Are you here for your... live fire exercise?
*KNOCK*
Captain?
No - I'm afraid we have to reschedule. There's a different kind of live fire exercise pending.
Ah. Seems like there usually is.
@BATTLE
